adaptive_features.formula: Adaptive immunity is antigen-specific, develops after exposure, and forms immunological memory
adaptive_features.correct: Adaptive responses are slower initially but generate memory cells for faster, stronger secondary responses

wrong.answer: Adaptive immunity responds immediately to all pathogens
wrong.fix: Adaptive immunity is delayed (days); innate provides immediate, non-specific defence
wrong.action: Innate = immediate; Adaptive = delayed but specific

wrong.answer: Adaptive immunity recognises pathogen patterns
wrong.error: Applying innate recognition to adaptive immunity
wrong.fix: Adaptive immunity recognises specific antigens via receptors; innate recognises PAMPs
wrong.action: Adaptive = specific antigens; Innate = pathogen patterns

wrong.answer: Memory responses are the same strength as primary
wrong.fix: Memory responses are faster, stronger, and longer-lasting than primary responses
wrong.action: Secondary response > Primary response (faster, stronger, longer)

persistent.gap: Confusion between innate and adaptive immunity characteristics
persistent.action: Adaptive: specific, delayed, memory-forming; Innate: non-specific, immediate, no memory

antigen_presentation.formula: Antigen-presenting cells process antigens and display them on MHC molecules for T cell recognition
antigen_presentation.correct: MHC class I presents endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells; MHC class II presents exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells

wrong.answer: All cells present antigens on MHC class II
wrong.fix: MHC II is only on professional APCs; MHC I is on all nucleated cells
wrong.action: MHC I = all nucleated cells; MHC II = APCs only

wrong.answer: CD8+ T cells recognise MHC class II
wrong.error: Mixing up T cell subsets and MHC classes
wrong.fix: CD8+ recognises MHC I; CD4+ recognises MHC II (8÷4=2, so CD8 → MHC I)
wrong.action: CD8+ → MHC I; CD4+ → MHC II

wrong.answer: T cells recognise free antigens in blood
wrong.fix: T cells only recognise antigens presented on MHC molecules, not free antigens
wrong.action: T cells need MHC presentation; B cells can recognise free antigens

persistent.action: MHC I + endogenous antigen → CD8+ T cell; MHC II + exogenous antigen → CD4+ T cell

clonal_selection.formula: Clonal selection is when antigen binding activates specific lymphocytes to proliferate and differentiate
clonal_selection.correct: Only lymphocytes with receptors matching the antigen are selected, then they clone themselves

wrong.answer: Antigens cause all lymphocytes to divide
wrong.fix: Only lymphocytes with matching receptors are activated; others remain naive
wrong.action: Specific antigen → specific lymphocyte activation (1:1 matching)

wrong.answer: Lymphocytes change their receptors to match antigens
wrong.fix: Receptor specificity is determined during development; antigens select matching cells
wrong.action: Receptors are fixed; antigens select cells with matching receptors

wrong.answer: Clonal selection occurs before antigen encounter
wrong.fix: Clonal selection requires antigen encounter to trigger proliferation
wrong.action: Sequence: diverse repertoire → antigen encounter → clonal selection

persistent.action: Process: antigen binds matching receptor → activation → proliferation → clone of identical cells

cell_mediated.formula: Cell-mediated immunity involves T cells directly killing infected cells or coordinating immune responses
cell_mediated.correct: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+) kill infected cells; Helper T cells (CD4+) activate other immune cells via cytokines

wrong.answer: Helper T cells kill infected cells
wrong.error: Confusing helper and cytotoxic T cell functions
wrong.fix: Helpers coordinate (via cytokines); Cytotoxic T cells do the killing
wrong.action: CD4+ helpers = coordinate; CD8+ cytotoxic = kill

wrong.answer: Cell-mediated immunity involves antibodies
wrong.fix: Cell-mediated = T cell responses; Humoral = antibody responses (B cells)
wrong.action: Cell-mediated = T cells; Humoral = B cells + antibodies

wrong.answer: Cytotoxic T cells kill by phagocytosis
wrong.fix: Cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis in target cells using perforin and granzymes
wrong.action: CTLs release perforin (pores) + granzymes (trigger apoptosis)

persistent.action: CD8+ = kill infected cells (perforin/granzymes); CD4+ = helper (cytokines)

humoral_immunity.formula: Humoral immunity involves B cells producing antibodies that neutralise pathogens and mark them for destruction
humoral_immunity.correct: B cells differentiate into plasma cells that secrete antibodies; antibodies work in body fluids

wrong.answer: B cells directly kill pathogens
wrong.fix: B cells produce antibodies that mark pathogens; other cells do the killing
wrong.action: B cells = antibody factories; Antibodies = mark targets

wrong.answer: Antibodies kill pathogens inside cells
wrong.fix: Antibodies work outside cells (humoral = fluid); cell-mediated immunity targets intracellular pathogens
wrong.action: Antibodies = extracellular; T cells = intracellular pathogens

wrong.answer: All activated B cells become plasma cells
wrong.fix: Some B cells become plasma cells (immediate); some become memory cells (future)
wrong.action: B cell activation → plasma cells + memory B cells

persistent.action: B cell → plasma cell → antibodies (extracellular pathogens) + memory B cells

antibody_structure.formula: Antibodies have variable regions that bind antigens and constant regions that determine antibody class and function
antibody_structure.correct: The Fab region binds antigen; the Fc region binds immune cells and complement

wrong.answer: Antibodies bind antigens with their constant region
wrong.error: Reversing variable and constant region functions
wrong.fix: Variable regions bind antigens (they vary to match different antigens); constant regions have effector functions
wrong.action: Variable = antigen binding; Constant = effector function

wrong.answer: All antibodies are identical
wrong.fix: Each antibody has unique variable regions; constant regions define the class (IgG, IgM, etc.)
wrong.action: Variable = unique per antibody; Constant = same within class

wrong.answer: Antibodies have only one antigen-binding site
wrong.fix: Most antibodies have two antigen-binding sites (bivalent); IgM has ten
wrong.action: IgG = 2 binding sites; IgM = 10 binding sites

persistent.gap: Confusion about antibody structure and function
persistent.action: Antibody: 2 Fab regions (bind antigen) + 1 Fc region (effector function)

antibody_functions.formula: Antibodies neutralise pathogens, opsonise for phagocytosis, and activate complement
antibody_functions.correct: Different antibody classes have different functions: IgG opsonises, IgM activates complement, IgE triggers allergies

wrong.answer: All antibody classes have the same function
wrong.fix: Each class has specialised functions: IgA at mucosae, IgE for allergies, IgG for opsonisation
wrong.action: IgG=opsonise, IgM=complement, IgA=mucosal, IgE=allergy, IgD=B cell receptor

wrong.answer: Antibodies directly kill pathogens
wrong.fix: Antibodies mark pathogens; killing requires phagocytes, complement, or NK cells
wrong.action: Antibodies = target markers; Other cells/proteins = killers

wrong.answer: IgM is the main antibody in secondary responses
wrong.error: Confusing primary and secondary response antibodies
wrong.fix: IgM dominates primary responses; IgG dominates secondary (memory) responses
wrong.action: Primary = IgM first; Secondary = mainly IgG

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of antibody diversity and function
persistent.action: Functions: neutralisation, opsonisation, complement activation, ADCC

immunological_memory.formula: Memory cells persist after infection and enable faster, stronger responses upon re-exposure
immunological_memory.correct: Memory B and T cells have lower activation thresholds and respond more quickly than naive cells

wrong.answer: Memory cells are activated during the first infection
wrong.fix: Effector cells fight current infection; memory cells form for future encounters
wrong.action: First infection: effector cells; Re-infection: memory cells respond

wrong.answer: Memory responses take the same time as primary
wrong.fix: Memory responses are much faster (days vs weeks) and produce more antibodies
wrong.action: Primary: 1-2 weeks; Secondary: 1-3 days

wrong.answer: Memory cells need help from dendritic cells
wrong.error: Applying naive cell requirements to memory
wrong.fix: Memory cells can respond directly to antigen without APC help
wrong.action: Naive cells need APC presentation; Memory cells respond directly

persistent.action: Memory = faster (days), stronger (more antibody), longer-lasting response on re-exposure
